Posts.Content: Congrats RLT. I'm one of those on the choice fence, deciding between radiation and surgery. Nice to hear your good results.
Posts.Title: Thanks for the peace of mind R.L.T.

Posts.Content: Bunnabrock, I'm sorry to hear about your husband's diagnosis. Although I'm not well versed enough to tackle your questions, I just wanted to wish you the best of luck and success in your husband's treatment and future. I've only recently been diagnosed myself with prostate cancer and I'm still searching my around the information gathering.
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed metastatic prostate cancer--PSA and testosterone levels

Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed metastatic prostate cancer--PSA and testosterone levels

Posts.Content: Hello. Im new to the site here. Ill be 66 in April and Ive been pretty healthy until my recent prostate cancer diagnosis. I take no medication. I am retired. I hike about 8 miles a couple of times a week and do a lot of shorter walk/hikes between those longer ones. I have been good about having annual physicals and the PSA score was never an issue until about a year ago. It went up to <5 in December 2013, then up to <9 in December 2014. The latter score resulted in me seeing a urologist, who took 6 biopsies and they revealed cancer on both sides of the prostate, with a Gleason level of 7 on each side. His estimation of my staging was between 2 and 3. Although I dont have the details of what the sublevels were that resulted in the 7 score, he told me it did not appear to be aggressive. Last week I had both a lower abdomen scan and a complete bone scan done. Neither of those showed any evidence that the cancer has spread from the prostate. My prostate is a little swollen but I have little to no issues with getting up at night to urinate, etc. A small issue here or there with semi-frequent urination during the day or slightly weak flow rate, but thats about it. I already visited with one radiation oncologist and Im scheduled to have a consult with a surgeon tomorrow. I have asked to speak with a different radiation oncologist tomorrow as well, only because the treatment facility is much better than that of the first radiation oncologist I saw. I got divorced a couple of years ago and Im not crazy about entering into another marriage or live-in situation with anyone else. I live alone and the bathroom and bedroom are both on the 2nd floor. There really isnt anyone available to care for me, such like a live-in partner or wife would. The ability or inability about future sexual function is not important to me. I go into this boring detail because they are the kinds of things I consider in determining how to choose which treatment option I go with. The medical facility I will be using is a drive of about an hour from home. I dont really mind having to do that daily for a couple of months, if I go with the external radiation beam treatment. I have read through many posts here and theyve been quite informative. But its decision time for me in choosing a treatment option. Obviously, I would like to be cancer free. My longer hiking activity is usually with a small group of people. Thus, long-term incontinence would be a concern for me and something I would really like to avoid. Today, Im leaning toward external radiation beam therapy but Ill probably learn a lot more tomorrow when at the Lehigh Valley Hospital in Allentown, PA. Any input would be appreciated. Cheers.

Posts.Content: That's good to hear, Adam. Congrats on being cancer free. I'm in the early stage of information collection and evaluation.
Posts.Title: Post Robotic Prostate Cancer Surgery - 3 years later
